results.headline: Only a Few More Smuggling Days Left Before Christmas? It’s Not a Wonderful Life
results.summary_short: Courtney Hunt’s somber film “Frozen River” ventures deep into the trenches where hard-working Americans struggle to put food on the table.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frozen River

results.headline: A Struggle Toward Manhood
results.summary_short: “Sixty Six” is a dolorous comedy that leans heavily, if inoffensively, on ethnic stereotypes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sixty Six

results.headline: Hopeful Misanthrope Seeks Same
results.summary_short: Lightly sweetened and just a touch bitter, the romantic comedy “In Search of a Midnight Kiss” treads familiar if appealing ground.
results.display_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Search of a Midnight Kiss

results.headline: What You See
results.summary_short: Clueless, directionless and altogether pointless, “America the Beautiful” will outrage only those who have spent the last 50 years in suspended animation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of America the Beautiful

results.headline: Hey, America, This Guy’s for You
results.summary_short: “Swing Vote” is one of the most surprising, politically suggestive movies to come out of Hollywood this year.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Swing Vote

results.headline: A Glitch in the System
results.summary_short: “Stealing America: Vote by Vote” might have been this year’s most alarming and patriotic documentary if it weren’t so shoddy and dull.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stealing America: Vote by Vote

results.headline: Curses
results.summary_short: The third installment of the “Mummy” franchise, “Tomb of the Dragon Emperor,” is by far the weakest.

results.headline: Holding an All Saints’ Day of American Radicals
results.summary_short: “Profit Motive and the Whispering Wind” contemplates the violence and struggle of the past by examining markers and monuments across the country.

results.headline: A Mardi Gras Story in Black and White
results.summary_short: “The Order of Myths” is a wise and soberly affecting documentary about the separate but unequal Mardi Gras festivities that take place each year in Mobile, Ala.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Order of Myths

results.headline: Walking on Air Between the Towers
results.summary_short: James Marsh’s “Man on Wire” is a thorough, understated and altogether enthralling documentary.

results.headline: Returning to the Scene of a Crime Movie
results.summary_short: “Back to Normandy” takes a look at how the making of a film affected the village where it was set.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Back to Normandy

results.headline: Sexual Identity Collides With Economic Need
results.summary_short: In overlighted hallways and shady side rooms, the director, Leesong Hee-il, presents a remarkably frank portrait of low-rent South Korean homosexuality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Regret

results.headline: Who’s Afraid of the Darkly Paranormal?
results.summary_short: Baggy, draggy, oddly timed and strangely off the mark, “The X-Files: I Want to Believe” is the generally bad-news follow-up to the show’s first feature-film incarnation.

results.headline: Lives of Real Adolescents, in Very Deep Close-Up
results.summary_short: The documentary “American Teen” is the kind of movie the people in it might have made.

results.headline: The Politics of Song
results.summary_short: “CSNY: Déjà Vu” has some delicious moments, but you never quite shake the feeling that it’s documenting a tempest in a teapot.

results.headline: A Child’s Odyssey
results.summary_short: “Canary” finds inspiration in the deadly sarin nerve gas attacks in the Tokyo subway in 1995.

results.headline: Making a Splash

results.headline: Bright Young Things in Love and Pain
